tossups.question: Cabral and Leedom proposed a method for visualizing these mathematical objects called LIC, which assigns values to pixels using a convolution kernel. These objects and their components can be visualized using a quiver plot. Ugly animation flips result when one tries to visualize two of these objects in R3 that are both orthogonal to each other and non-zero at every point, due to a result called the hairy ball theorem. By traversing particles through a specific type of these objects, one can generate a (*) streamline and visualize a flow. If one of these objects is irrotational, then it is also conservative, meaning it is defined by the gradient of a function. Forces such as gravity are represented using, for 10 points, what constructs in which every point in space has a magnitude and direction?
tossups.answer: vector fields [accept velocity fields; accept force fields until “force” is read, but prompt after; prompt on fields; prompt on vectors, vector spaces, vector-valued functions, vector functions, or vector plots] <WA, Applied Math/Misc>

tossups.question: A jurist of this first name published the Commendation of the Laws of England and became Chancellor of England during the exile of a king. A nobleman of this name married Constance of Castille and insisted that fellow lords call him “my lord of Spain” as part of his failed bid for the Castilian crown. That nobleman of this name became Chaucer’s brother-in-law and formed the House of Lancaster by marrying Blanche of Lancaster. A king of this name allied with the Holy Roman Emperor (*) Otto IV, but still lost to the forces of Philip II Augustus at the Battle of Bouvines (“boo-VEEN”). After that loss, that king of this name went to a meeting at Runnymede and ceded power to English lords in the Magna Carta. For 10 points, give this name of a ruler nicknamed “Lackland,” the only English ruler of that name.
tossups.answer: John [accept John Fortescue, John of Gaunt, John Lackland, or John I] <ML, European History>

tossups.question: To join a group led by this man, an applicant had to be buried in the ground chest-high and defend himself from nine spearmen using only a hazel stick and a shield. This man was trapped by three hags who enchanted him to lose his strength while entering a cave with his friend Conan. This man’s grandson Oscar threatened him to get him to heal a rival with a “love spot.” However, this man let water (*) slip through his fingers rather than save that man who had seduced his betrothed Grainne (“GRON-yuh”), named Diarmuid (“DEER-mid”). This hero, who fathered the bard Ossian, could recall knowledge by sucking on the thumb he burned while cooking the Salmon of Knowledge. For 10 points, name this hero from Irish Myth who leads the Fianna (“FEE-uh-nuh”).
tossups.answer: Fionn mac Cumhaill [or Finn MacCool] <ML, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: The possession of one of these documents was found to be a protected right under the Fifth Amendment in the case Kent v. Dulles. Twelve of the fifteen members of CARICOM use a common example of these documents, whose creation is generally credited to Henry V (“the fifth”) of England. Images that only display under black lights are uniquely found on examples of these documents from Canada. Russia is the only country that still has an (*) “internal” example of these documents. In the UK, citizens will begin receiving traditional blue examples of these documents, rather than so-called “red books,” after Brexit. In the US, you may apply for one of these documents using a DS-11 form at a post office. For 10 points, name these documents that may be stamped upon entry into a new country.
tossups.answer: passports [accept internal passports] <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.question: A quote from an epic poem describes how the “victorious cause” of this man “pleased the gods” and contrasts it with the “vanquished cause.” In another appearance, this man describes himself as “constant as the Northern Star” while discussing his banishment of Cimber. This man ascends to heaven following a speech by Pythagoras at the end of Ovid’s Metamorphoses. He is the primary [emphasize] antagonist of the best-known epic by Lucan (“LOO-kin”). This man describes another character with a (*) “lean and hungry look” who “thinks too much” in a play that mentions his three refusals of “a kingly crown,” in a speech delivered to bury this man, “not to praise him.” In that play, this man ignores warnings by a soothsayer and his wife Calpurnia. For 10 points, what man says “Et tu” prior to his assassination by Brutus?
tossups.answer: Julius Caesar [or Gaius Julius Caesar] <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: Kenneth Arrow’s book on the “Economics of” this commodity explains why its characteristics create problems for industrial structure. Rapid dispersal of this commodity is a key assumption of the strong form of the efficient market hypothesis. The distribution of this commodity explains why the average medical condition of insurance applicants decreases as insurance prices rise, according to a 1970 article. Parties in transactions can be made to give up an (*) advantage in this commodity via “screening.” Such advantages in this commodity prior to transactions can result in adverse selection or moral hazard. George Akerlof’s paper “The Market for ‘Lemons’” shows how market failures can result from asymmetric access to, for 10 points, what commodity that is roughly synonymous with knowledge?
tossups.answer: information [prompt on knowledge; do not accept or prompt on “data”] <CQ, Social Science: Econ>

tossups.question: This president received a secret surgery for epithelioma while on the yacht Oneida (“oh-NYE-duh”). This president bends behind a chariot in a political cartoon that depicts his loss to the “Sugar Trust.” The Interstate Commerce Act was passed under this president to regulate the railroad industry. Due to an economic panic, this president supported the repeal of the Sherman (*) Silver Purchase Act. He was the only [emphasize] incumbent president in US history to lose an election despite winning the popular vote. This man’s affair with Maria Halpin led his opponent to use the slogan “Ma, Ma, Where’s My Pa,” but he still beat James G. Blaine in the election of 1884. For 10 points, name this only president to ever serve two nonconsecutive terms in the White House.
tossups.answer: Grover Cleveland <ML, US History>

tossups.question: A poem written in this language describes using logic to define “is,” “is-not,” and “up-and-down.” President Obama quoted a poem in this language stating that the “children of Adam are limbs to each other, having been created of one essence.” The poems and stories in The Rose Garden are in this language, which was used for a poem that commands “Wake!” because the Sun has “scattered into flight / The Stars.” Another poem in this language ends by exclaiming (*) “Oh, Wilderness were Paradise enow!” A form in this language consisting of a quatrain in AABA was used for a poem that notes “The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, / Moves on.” Edward Fitzgerald translated a line in this language as “A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread – and Thou.” For 10 points, Sa’di wrote in what language used to write Omar Khayyam’s Rubaiyat?
tossups.answer: Persian [or Farsi] <AR, Poetry>

tossups.question: A book by this philosopher uses the similar terms “historic a priori” and “positive unconscious of knowledge” to describe underlying currents in thought. Another book by this philosopher describes the project of post-Kantian philosophy using Martin Heidegger’s term “analytic of finitude.” In a third book, he claims that transitioning between medieval times and the Age of Reason produced an epistemic shift, resulting in a “great (*) confinement” being imposed on certain people who were once revered. That book by this author of The Order of Things begins with an analysis of the Ship of Fools, and gives a history of insanity in the West. For 10 points, name this French author of Madness and Civilization who wrote about the penal system in Discipline and Punish.
tossups.answer: Michel Foucault [or Paul-Michel Foucault] (The first clue is from The Archaeology of Knowledge.) <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.question: Troops from the 3rd and 5th armies loyal to this faction got involved in a 20th-century Opium War in which they fought warlord Khun Sa’s troops for control of smuggling routes. Despite instituting several drug bans, this faction’s leaders happily took bribes from Green Gang smugglers, who in turn helped carry out one of two distinct purges by this faction called the White Terror. This faction opened the (*) Whampoa Academy during the 1920s, in which it began several campaigns to end the Warlord Era. This party’s armies were successfully [emphasize] evaded during the Long March, whose leader forced this party off the mainland in a civil war that ended in 1949. For 10 points, name this party that has ruled the Republic of China for most of its history, including under Chiang Kai-Shek.
tossups.answer: Kuomintang [or Guomindang; or KMT; accept Chinese Nationalist Party or Nationalist Party of China or NCP or CNP or Chinese Nationalists; prompt on Nationalists until “China” is read, but accept after] <WA, World History>

tossups.question: The feminist artist Tanja Ostojić (“Tanya OSS-toh-yeech”) recreated one of this artist’s paintings by posing in blue underwear in her work E.U. Panties. Jacques Lacan (“la-CON”) was the longtime owner of that painting by this artist, which was commissioned by Khalil Bey. Like Géricault, he was criticized heavily at a Salon for mis-appropriating the genre of history painting for a work with a large cross in the background. This artist’s painting of a “Beautiful Irishwoman” depicts Joanna Hiffernan, who likely modeled for his painting of (*) hairy female genitalia. He used his hometown as the setting of a large painting showing mourners in an S-shape as a dog and a kneeling man look into a freshly-dug hole. For 10 points, name this French painter of The Origin of the World who won fame with his realist depiction of a funeral, titled A Burial at Ornans (“or-NAWN”).
tossups.answer: Gustave Courbet <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: Melania Trump is imagined as a modern version of this character in a story written in anticipation of the 2016 US election by Chimamanda Adichie (“uh-DEE-chay”) titled “The Arrangements.” This character hears a clock’s chime as “leaden (“LED-in”) circles dissolved in the air” and feels “far out to sea and alone” watching taxi cabs during her trip to Bond Street. This character, who first appeared in the novel The Voyage Out, reflects on her decision to marry the politician Richard rather than (*) Peter Walsh. Her happiest moment was during her summer at Bourton, where she kissed Sally Seton. This character decides to “buy the flowers herself” at the beginning of a novel in which the shell-shocked Septimus Smith commits suicide by jumping out of a window. For 10 points, name this title woman who hosts a party in a novel by Virginia Woolf.
tossups.answer: Mrs. Dalloway [or Clarissa Dalloway] <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: The abundance of these particles was limited in 2017 by the MoEDAL experiment. Solutions to Yang–Mills field equations in SU(2) (“S-U-two”) known as merons behave like an example of these entities co-named for Yang. Two of these entities can be connected by a type of one-dimensional curve that is [emphasize] not gauge (“gayj”)-invariant and is called one physicist’s namesake “string.” These entities appear at singularities in the (*) vector potential. These entities exist if the electric charge is quantized according to a condition formulated by Paul Dirac. Incorporating these entities into Maxwell’s equations makes the equations fully symmetric. The statement that the divergence of the B-field is zero, alternatively known as Gauss’s law, implies that these entities do not exist. For 10 points, name these point-sources of magnetic fields, which are contrasted with the common dipole.
tossups.answer: magnetic monopoles [accept Wu–Yang monopoles or Dirac monopoles] <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: The sea captain Lorenzo Dow Baker introduced this crop to America before partnering with Andrew Preston to form a company that became its largest producer. Companies based in New Orleans that primarily imported this crop included one run by the Vaccaro brothers and one run by Sam Zemurray. An author’s time living with Al Jennings led him to coin a term referring to this crop in Cabbages and Kings. It’s not wheat, but a company whose nickname was “The (*) Octopus” or “El Pulpo” mainly produced this crop and pressured the US to remove Jacobo Árbenz, the president of Guatemala, after he confiscated their land. That producer of this crop, which exercised massive influence over Central American governments, was United Fruit. An O. Henry quip named corrupt Latin American governments after, for 10 points, what fruits?
tossups.answer: bananas [accept banana republic] <JM, Commonwealth/Misc>

tossups.question: This film cuts from a tracking shot in which a woman’s head nearly falls out of the frame as she descends into a forest, to a close-up of that woman gazing through the branches. A sequence in this film ends with a woman dressed in men’s clothing watching the collapse of an inn’s second floor. In a long flashback in this film, a woman pursues a man through the desert on horseback to retrieve her comb. In its final scene, that woman acts out a story that she heard from her lover by jumping off a bridge and (*) gliding away into a sea of fog. Tan Dun composed the score to this wuxia (“woo-shyah”) film, in which the Green Destiny Sword is stolen by an apprentice of Jade Fox, one of whose poison darts kills Li Mu Bai as he confesses his love to Yu Shi Lien. Michelle Yeoh (“yo”) and Chow Yun-Fat star in, for 10 points, what martial arts film by Ang Lee?
tossups.answer: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon [or Wòhǔ Cánglóng] <WA, Other Arts: Film>

tossups.question: A story about four animals standing on top of each other ends when they determine that a partridge who represents this man is the oldest of them. In another story, this man is presented with visions of the three beautiful daughters of a demon who embodies “unskillful emotions,” but sits still and resists. The first time that this man left his palace in (*) Lumbini, he saw an old man, a sick man, and a dead man on the road. This man, who resisted the temptations of Mara and experienced the “four sights,” convened a group of followers in the deer park at Sarnath. There, he taught that people can escape from the infinite cycle of rebirth, or samsara, by following the Noble Eightfold Path. For 10 points, name this man born Siddhartha Gautama.
tossups.answer: Buddha [accept Siddhartha or Gautama until read; accept Shakyamuni or Amida] <JM, Religion>

tossups.question: A simple Unix command of this name has a dash-f option to watch changes to a log file. If factorial calls itself at the end so that n and the accumulator are multiplied inside the parameter list, then it uses a special technique of this name that bypasses stack frames and is equivalent to a loop. Haskell’s function of this name decomposes a list as “underscore colon xs” and returns xs. Scheme and ES6 use trampolines to optimize or eliminate a special case of (*) recursion known by this name. By default, a Unix command of this name displays a file’s last 10 lines. This noun can refer to a call at the very end of a function, or to a list without its first element. A doubly linked list has pointers to the head node and a node of this name. For 10 points, give this term for long thin areas at a statistical distribution’s extremes or bright escaping streams from a comet.
tossups.answer: tail [accept tail recursion, tail-recursive, tail call optimization, tail call elimination, tail call, or tail node; prompt on recursion; prompt on rest by asking “what noun is the function usually named for?”] <OL, Computer Science>

tossups.question: A lively prelude in 9/8 (“nine-eight”) time depicting these characters opens with a series of string half-scales rising to meet the winds’ increasingly higher F-sharp trills. One of these operatic characters outlines a G augmented triad for the cry “Hojotoho!” (“HO-yo-toh-ho”). Horns play a low F-sharp pickup, then “B, short low F-sharp, B,” then the long notes “D, B,” to start the fanfare-like (*) leitmotif (“LIGHT-moh-teef”) representing these characters at the start of Act 3. A sleeping one of these figures is reached by a man who passes through a ring of fire. Wotan (“VOH-tahn”) declares that, as punishment for saving Siegmund (“ZEEG-moont”), one of these characters must become mortal. For 10 points, what characters in Wagner’s Ring Cycle, including Brünnhilde and her fellow warrior-maidens, “ride” flying horses in a namesake opera?
tossups.answer: Valkyries [or Die Walküre; accept “Ride of the Valkyries” or “Walkürenritt”; accept shieldmaidens; do not accept or prompt on “women” or “Rhine maidens”] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: This author described a programmer who uses a computer to determine how Roessler, Ogiva, Inigo, and Belindo Kind died in his Oulipo (“oo-lee-poh”)-inspired story “The Burning of the Abominable House.” He included “The Little Girl Sold with the Pears” in a 1956 collection of 200 of his country’s folktales. The protagonist of a story by this author enters a love triangle with Captain Vhd Vhd (“vood vood”) and his wife while collecting milk from the moon’s surface. The (*) hard-to-pronounce Qfwfq (“KOOF-kuh”) narrates many of the stories in this author’s Cosmicomics. The protagonist of a novel by this author encounters the eccentric Professor Uzzi-Tuzii and marries Ludmilla. The odd-numbered chapters of that novel by this author concern you, the Reader. For 10 points, name this author of If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler.
tossups.answer: Italo Calvino <RK, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: A test developed to screen these drugs in mice is named for Porsolt. A class of these drugs that lowers the seizure threshold is also used to help quit smoking. They aren’t NSAIDs (“EN-seds”), but there’s controversy about whether one class of these drugs causes persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn when taken by pregnant women. Discontinuation of one class of these drugs can cause brain zaps. Amitriptyline (“am-uh-TRIP-tuh-leen”) and (*) nortriptyline (“nor-uh-TRIP-tuh-leen”) are examples of the tricyclic class of these drugs, which target the protein SERT. These drugs are prescribed if the PHQ9 or SIG-E-CAPS tests are positive. These drugs, which include MAOIs, SNRIs, and SSRIs, can paradoxically increase the risk of suicide for one month. For 10 points, name these drugs, such as paroxetine or sertraline, that are used to elevate mood.
tossups.answer: antidepressants [prompt on psych drugs or psychotropic drugs; accept more specific answers like MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCA, or tricyclic until read] <JZ, Biology: Medicine>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: William Seward introduced this amendment into the Senate, which would have prevented the federal government from interfering in “domestic institutions” of the states. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this amendment that attempted to provide a compromise and stave off the Civil War. It passed the Senate but only five states ratified it before the Civil War.

An earlier attempt to prevent the Civil War was the compromise named for this year. The compromise named for this year passed the Fugitive Slave Act and allowed California to enter the union as a free state.
This former president’s call for a peace conference before the passage of the Corwin Amendment led to a conference in 1861. Several members of his Cabinet were killed in the USS Princeton disaster.

bonuses.leadin: Rabbinic literature contrasts this place with Gehenna, a similarly dark location intended as a place of punishment. For 10 points each:
answers: Maimonides [or Moshe ben Maimon; prompt on Moshe; prompt on Rambam until read] <WA, Religion>
parts: Name this dreary netherworld inhabited by shades called rephaim (“re-fah-EEM”).
In the Bible, Saul asks the Witch of Endor to summon this prophet from Sheol in order to give him counsel. This prophet names the two books of the Bible that tell the stories of Saul and David.

This Jewish writer’s 13 Articles of Faith imply a belief in Sheol or another form of afterlife, as they include the resurrection of the dead. This rabbi, known as Rambam (“ROM-bom”), wrote the Mishneh Torah.

bonuses.leadin: This book concludes with an examination of the “Future Condition of Three Races,” in which it notes that General Jackson would “infallibly… forfeit his political station” if he sought to become a despot. For 10 points each:
answers: Democracy in America [or On Democracy in America or De La Démocratie en Amérique]
parts: Name this two-volume treatise, published in 1835 and 1840 after its author was sponsored by the July Monarchy to study foreign prison systems.
Democracy in America is a book by this French political scientist.

A less positive view of America was taken by this Victorian, who promoted the abolitionist cause in Britain through her book Society in America. This pioneering female sociologist wrote Illustrations of Political Economy and translated much of Auguste Comte’s work into English.

bonuses.leadin: In one novel set under this government, the protagonist kills both a defrocked priest who propositions him and his neighbor, a dissident university professor. For 10 points each:
answers: Fascist Italy [prompt on fascism; prompt on Italy; accept the Mussolini regime]
parts: Name this government, the setting of The Conformist, which was critiqued in an essay that lists 14 principles of its ideology, including a cult of tradition, action for action’s sake, and selective populism.
The latter essay, “Ur-Fascism” was written by this author, better known for his novels Foucault’s Pendulum and The Name of the Rose.

The final principle of Eco’s essay claims that “Ur-Fascism speaks” this language. The appendix of a novel claims this “official language of Oceania” was “devised to meet the ideological needs of Ingsoc (“ING-sohsh”).”

bonuses.leadin: According to the Trivers–Willard hypothesis, this variable is adjusted by mothers based on conditions. For 10 points each:
answers: sex ratio [prompt on descriptive answers like gender ratio or ratio of males to females]
hermaphrodite [or word forms such as hermaphroditic] <EM, Biology: EEB>
parts: Name this quantity, which is one-to-one at equilibrium according to Fisher’s principle.
In many species of reptiles, the sex ratio is dependent on this variable, a phenomenon whose evolution was modelled by Charnov and Bull.

Sequential examples of these creatures produce one type of gamete at one stage of life, then switch to producing the other type later. This is the name given to organisms that can produce both eggs and sperm.

bonuses.leadin: A 1923 film adaptation of this play starring Alla Nazimova is often considered to be one of the first art films made in the US. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Oscar Wilde play that was adapted into an opera in which a highly dissonant polytonal chord plays as the title character kisses Jochanaan’s (“yo-HAH-nan’s”) head.
The opera Salome is by this German composer of Der Rosenkavalier (“dare ROH-zen-KAH-vuh-leer”) and Also Sprach Zarathustra (“ALL-zoh shprock tsah-rah-TOOS-trah”).

This artist’s black-and-white illustrations of Salome include The Peacock Skirt, which shows a towering Salome wearing the title garment and speaking with a timid youth. This Aestheticist artist also illustrated the magazine he co-founded, The Yellow Book.

bonuses.leadin: Scales of apparent magnitude have historically often used this star as a standard to define an apparent magnitude of zero. For 10 points each:
answers: B minus V [do not accept or prompt on any other answers]
Hertzsprung–Russell diagrams [or HR diagrams or HRDs] <WA, Astronomy>
parts: Name this brightest star in the constellation Lyra. It is the standard for magnitude zero on color indices.

Specifically, Vega is used as a standard for zero color in UBV indices. In terms of the blue magnitude B and the visual magnitude V, give the formula for the color index that is most commonly used for stars with mid-range temperatures.

A color index such as B minus V is plotted against luminosity on these diagrams used in stellar classification. The main sequence forms a diagonal going from the upper left to lower right on these diagrams.

bonuses.leadin: A group named for this city advocated for a closely-integrated socialist pan-African federation and feuded with the capitalist-oriented Monrovia Group. For 10 points each:
answers: Organization of African Unity [or OAU] <JM, World History>
parts: Name this largest city in Morocco. It titles a 1944 Michael Curtiz film in which Humphrey Bogart’s character helps Ingrid Bergman’s character flee to Portugal.

The driving force behind the Casablanca group was this leader of the Convention People’s Party, who was later overthrown in a coup by Joseph Ankrah. This leader secured independence for a colony that was then known as the Gold Coast.
The Monrovia Group eventually triumphed, establishing this international body and predecessor of the African Union.

bonuses.leadin: The Marche en rondeau prelude from Marc-Antoine Charpentier’s (“shar-pont-YAY’s”) setting of this hymn was used as the signature tune of the Eurovision Song Contest. For 10 points each:
answers: Te Deum (“tay DAY-um”) [or Te deum laudamus; prompt on “We Praise Thee, O God”]
D major [do not accept or prompt on “D minor”] <RK, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this hymn. While conducting his setting of this hymn to celebrate Louis XIV’s recovery from surgery, a different composer struck his foot with a staff and later died of gangrene.

Charpentier’s setting of the Te Deum is a piece in this genre. They’re not masses, but Palestrina composed hundreds of these polyphonic choral works set to Latin religious texts, including Exsultate Deo, Sicut cervus, and Stabat Mater.
Charpentier’s Te Deum is in this major key. Many violin concertos, including those by Brahms, Beethoven, and Tchaikovsky, are in this major key with two sharps.

bonuses.leadin: Mayura is the mythological version of these animals in Hindu traditions. For 10 points each:
answers: Olorun [or Olodumare; do not accept or prompt on “Olokun”]
parts: Name these animals, some of which provide objects that are often shown in Krishna’s hair. When Hermes killed the hundred-eyed Argus, Hera put his eyes on this animal.

In Yoruba (“YO-roo-ba”) tradition, the peacock was turned into a vulture when it tried to fly to this chief orisha, who is the king of the heavens. This orisha works with Obatala to create land and humans.

The people of this city, who venerated Marduk as their chief god, regarded the peacock as one of their main symbols of royalty. Those residents of this city believed that the gods granted authority to their king Hammurabi.

bonuses.leadin: A poem by Gregory Corso whose shape is inspired by one of these objects calls it “a paean an acme of scream / a lyric hat of Mister Thunder.” For 10 points each:
answers: Lawrence Ferlinghetti [or Lawrence Monsanto Ferlinghetti] (That poem is “Junkman’s Obbligato.”) <RK, Poetry>
parts: Name these objects. The speaker of another poem, dated “Berkeley, January 17, 1956,” says to the title country, “I’ve given you all and now I’m nothing” before telling it to “fuck itself” with one of these objects.
Gregory Corso and Allen Ginsberg, the authors of the poems “Bomb” and “America,” were both members of this counterculture “generation” of the 1950s.

This poet witnessed the aftermath of the bombing of Nagasaki while in the Navy. This co-founder of the City Lights bookstore described “looking like Walt Whitman / a homemade bomb in the pocket” in a poem from his collection A Coney Island of the Mind.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about post-independence art in India, for 10 points each.
answers: magazine cover [accept National Geographic cover or Nat Geo cover; prompt on cover]
parts: Cricket captain M. S. Dhoni was shown as a many-armed Vishnu in one of these images. Steve McCurry’s photograph of the blue-eyed girl Sharbat Gula is best known from its use as one of these images.
The post-Independence painter M. F. Husain depicted many Hindu deities in this manner. Botticelli’s Birth of Venus and Michelangelo’s Creation of Adam both depict their title figures in this manner.

This Indian-born artist decorated 16 large sandstone blocks with traditional Indian pigments to create the artwork Void Field, which was displayed at the 1990 Venice Biennale (“bee-en-NAH-lay”). This artist’s piece When I Am Pregnant consists of a mostly flat white wall with a single large bulge.

bonuses.leadin: Since the 1930s, this country’s foreign policy has largely adhered to the Estrada Doctrine, according to which it has not commented on the legitimacy of foreign governments and usually recognized them. For 10 points each:
answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
self-determination [do not accept or prompt on “self-government” or other answers] <WA, Commonwealth/Misc>
parts: Name this country. In the Bucareli Agreement, it received US recognition and clarified Article 27 of its constitution, according to which foreigners cannot own its natural resources.
Mexico adopted the Estrada Doctrine shortly after joining this international organization, the predecessor of the United Nations. The US never joined it, since the Senate did not ratify its charter.

The Estrada Doctrine thus rigidly adheres to this principle of international law, according to which people should choose their own sovereign. Point 10 of Woodrow Wilson’s Fourteen Points explicitly supports this principle, as do the League of Nations and UN charters.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote a poem that says “Could it here succeed / When scarcely twenty in the town can read?” to mock his hometown of Bristol. For 10 points each:
answers: epitaph [accept “Epitaph on Robert Canynge”; do not accept or prompt on “epigraph”] <ML, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this author who wrote in that poem “Rowley discharges all,” referencing a fictional 15th-century monk to which this author attributed many forgeries. His will ends “I leave my mother and my sister to the protection of my friends, if I have any” and was written before his suicide at age 17.

Chatterton’s will leaves some of these documents to young ladies, whom he assures need not worry about his ghost because he died for none of them. An epistolary novel collects many of these documents.
Chatterton wrote a work in this form “on Robert Canynge (“CAN-ing”).” This form commemorates someone who has died and is traditionally inscribed on their tombstone.

bonuses.leadin: This value is defined to be zero for the conversion of two hydrogen ions and two electrons into one molecule of hydrogen gas. For 10 points each:
answers: reduction potential [prompt on E or E-nought]
parts: Name this potential that quantifies the tendency of a compound to acquire electrons via a namesake type of reaction.

The redox reaction in the standard hydrogen electrode occurs on a surface made of the black form of this metal. DNA crosslinking chemotherapy drugs and catalytic converters contain this very valuable metal.

According to the Tafel equation, this quantity, the difference between a half-reaction’s calculated and experimental quantities, is dependent on the ratio of the observed current density to its value at equilibrium.

bonuses.leadin: A waterway of this type called Teche (“tesh”) was likely a past course of the Mississippi River. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of waterway whose name derives from a Choctaw word for “small stream.” This word mainly denotes low-lying swampy streams in the American South, especially in Louisiana.
This city in Harris County is connected to the Gulf of Mexico by Buffalo Bayou. This fourth most populous city in the US is part of a metropolitan area that includes Sugar Land and The Woodlands.
Another geographic term originating in the Southern US is this word for a river that runs parallel to another river’s floodplain. This term derives from the name of a river in Mississippi.

bonuses.leadin: Name these regions of Eastern and Southern Europe that have been shaped by historical imagination, for 10 points each.
answers: Balkans [or Balkan Peninsula; accept Imagining the Balkans]
Galicia [or Halicz; accept Galicia-Lodomeria; prompt on Ruthenia or Volhynia] <WA, European History>
parts: Maria Todorova’s book on “Imagining” this peninsula quotes Hermann Keyserling’s claim that this peninsula would need to be “invented” if it didn’t exist. Todorova is from Bulgaria on this peninsula.

Vesna Goldsworthy’s book Inventing Ruritania explores the “imperialism of the imagination” regarding this region of Eastern Europe, which is bordered by Wallachia to the south and the Carpathians to the east.

Larry Wolff’s book on “The Idea of” this region explores how “Hapsburg political culture” created it after the first partition of Poland. A historic “Petroleum Trail” crosses this region of Western Ukraine and Southern Poland.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity’s first, second, and third time derivatives are sometimes known as the snap, crackle, and pop, respectively. For 10 points each:
answers: periodic [or periodicity; or translational symmetry; prompt on symmetry] <RN, Physics>
parts: Name this quantity, the time derivative of acceleration. The recoil experienced by an accelerating charged particle emitting radiation is directly proportional to this quantity according to the Abraham–Lorentz equation.

The Larmor formula is used to calculate the amount of this quantity radiated by a particle in terms of its charge and acceleration. This quantity is equal to work over time, and it is measured in watts.
An easy derivation of the Abraham–Lorentz force assumes that the motion of the particle has this property. Particles in a medium with this property have wavefunctions described by the Bloch equation.

bonuses.leadin: In an unusual concession, the Red Cross was allowed to assist hundreds of victims of a 2004 explosion on one of these vehicles on the Tasado line, which is believed to have been an assassination attempt. For 10 points each:
answers: Kim Jong-un’s armored trains [accept any answer that indicates the trains used by leaders of North Korea; prompt on train or armored trains]
parts: Describe these vehicles whose interiors were uniquely recorded in 2011 during a state meeting with Russia. In February 2019, one of these vehicles traveled about 2,000 miles to reach Vietnam.
This first President of North Korea is believed to have begun his family’s custom of using armored trains to travel because he was scared of flying.

During Kim Jong-il’s 2001 visit to Russia, the train was reported to have stopped frequently to stock up on this wine from a namesake region of southwestern France. In 2016, Kim Jong-un claimed to have downed ten bottles of this wine in a single night.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s debut play pioneered drama in his country’s native dialect rather than Modern Standard Arabic. For 10 points each:
answers: Cleopatra [accept The Death of Cleopatra] <JM, Drama>
parts: Name this Egyptian dramatist of The People of the Cave who later became famous for plays like Song of Death, in which a university student is forced to carry out a blood feud for his family.

al-Hakim wrote a play with this title in which a man kills himself after destroying a sculpture. Eliza Doolittle is taught to lose her Cockney accent in an earlier play with this title by George Bernard Shaw.

al-Hakim’s contemporary Ahmed Shawqi wrote a play about this figure’s death that portrays her as heroic. Shawqi’s depiction contrasts with a Shakespearean depiction of this character in which Enobarbus claims “Age cannot wither… Her infinite variety.”
